Event: First photographic image using a camera obscura is taken by French inventor Joseph Nicéphore Niépce. This image later fades completely
Niépce creates the earliest known surviving photograph from nature, now known as View From the Window at La Gras , using a camera obscura and a heliography process
Hércules Florence, a French-Brazilian artist working primarily in Brazil, coins the word photographie
Louis-Jacques-Mandé Daguerre invents the daguerrotype process, requiring fewer than 30 minutes of exposure and producing fade-resistant images
French civil servant and and early photographer Hippolyte Bayard presents the first public exhibition of photographs in France

Niépce’s son and Louis Daguerre sell the rights to the daguerreotype and the heliograph to the French government. Later that year, working details of both technique are published and announced formally to the public via the French Academy of Sciences. Daguerre also publishes a best-selling publication, An Historical and Descriptive Account of the Various Processes of the Daguerreotype and the Diorama.
The British artist Sarah Anne Sarah Bright creates a series of photograms. The six extant photograms are the earliest known surviving photographic images by a woman.

American telegraph inventor Samuel Morse visits Daguerre's immersive Diorama photography installation in Paris, and returns to America with one of Daguerre's cameras. Shortly after his return, Morse and Dr. John W. Draper open their own photography studio, and create the first daguerrotype image taken in the United States
First American patent for a photographic mechanism granted to Alexander Wolcott
William Henry Talbot patents Calotype (or "Talbotype") process. This process allows for multiple photographic copies, and makes use of the photographic negative

The first photobook (or book to be fully illustrated by the means of images made by a photographic process), Photographs of British Algae. Cyanotype Impressions is published by British botanist and photographer Anna Atkins
The first professional woman photographer in Britain, Ann Cooke, opens her own studio
Antebellum photographer Mathew Brady opens the first New York City commercial photography studio and gallery, Daguerreian Miniature Gallery

Published in fasicles over two years, Henry Fox Talbot publishes The Pencil of Nature , a photobook of 24 plates and accompanying text, detailing the various applications for photography as a medium, including documenting architecture, surveying botanical specimens, reproducing rare manuscripts, and making art.
Friederich von Martens invents and patents an early panoramic camera, the Megaskop-Kamera, in Germany
Frederick Scott Archer invets the Collodion wet plate process, reducing the needed exposure time to just a few seconds

The first of the ninteenth-century world's fairs, the Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of All Nations , held in London's Hyde Park Crystal Palace, houses one of the earliest public exhibitions of photography, bringing together over 700 examples of photography from around the world
Exhibition of Recent Specimens of Photography , another of the world's first public exhibition dedicated solely to photographs, is held at the Society of Arts in London
Photographic Society of London (now Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain) is established in London
The Carte-de-visite (small, paper-mounted photograph portraiture) is patented in Paris
British Journal of Photography (initially the Liverpool Photographic Journal) publishes its first issue in January

Société française de photographie is founded in Paris, France by photographers and scientists, including Olympe Aguado, Hippolyte Bayard, Alexandre Edmond Becquerel, Eugène Durieu, Edmond Fierlants, Jean-Baptiste Louis Gros, Gustave Le Gray and Henri Victor Regnault

Roger Fenton, James Robertson, and Jean Charles Langlois all independently photograph the Crimean War (1853-1856) , in an early and relatively systematic approach to documenting war and conflict. In the years following, the fine art dealer Thomas Agnew and Sons would exhibit several of Fenton's Crimean war photographs, including the famous Valley of the Shadow of Death , as part of a series entitled Panorama of the Plateau of Sebastopol in Eleven Parts
Thomas Sutton patents his version of the panoramic camera in Great Britain
Thomas Sutton patents the single lens reflex camera
Mathew Brady finances a team of field photographers, including Alexander Gardner and Timothy H. O'Sullivan, to photograph the American Civil War

Carleton Watkins exhibits his mammoth plate and stereoview photographs of the Yosemite Valley (some of the earliest photographs taken of the American West) in a New York City gallery. The photographs, when presented to President Lincoln, constitute a significant part of the convincing evidence leading to Lincoln signing legislation to protect the land against mining, logging, and other development, essentially leading to an early form of the national parks system.
Shima Ryū creates the first photograph known to be taken by a Japanese woman
Julia Margaret Cameron joins the Photographic Society of Scotland, and her work is shown at the British Museum in a solo exhibtion

The Victoria and Albert Museum in London, England purchases 80 photographs by Julia Margaret Cameron, and grant her the use of two studios spaces in the museum, effectively making her an artist-in-residence
Leica is founded by Ernst Leitz in Germany
First halftone photograph, a portrait of Prince Arthur, is printed in Canadian Illustrated News
Richard Leach Maddox invents the gelatin dry plate silver bromide process
Eadweard Muybridge's experiments with high-speed photography on the west coast of the United States result in images of running horses
Founding of Eastman Dry Plate Company, which would become eventually become Eastman-Kodak
Étienne-Jules Marey invents the chronophotographic gun, capable of capturing twelve images in one second
George Eastman invents paper-based photographic film in Rochester, New York
Eastman patents the first roll-film camera for Eastman Kodak

Jacob Riis’s How the Other Half Lives: Studies among the Tenements of New York is published. It features drawings and half-tone photographic illustrations, while the subject matter focused on the lives of New York City's tenement and slum residents. An early example of photojournalism, its impact contributed to reforms in housing law and the creation of the New York Tenement House Act in 1895
Hannibal Goodwin patents celluloid photographic film
The Brownie, Kodak's first mass-market camera, goes on sale in the United States
Alfred Stieglitz founds the Photo-Secession group in New York City. Two years later, in 1904, Stieglitz will curate the first Photo-Secession exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, DC.

"International Exhibition of Pictorial Photography," organized by Steiglitz and installed by painter Max Weber, is exhibited at the Albright-Knox Gallery in Buffalo, New York . The exhibition aimed to re-contextualize photography beyond a scientific and mechanical process as an art form in its own right
The first Leica 35mm prototype cameras are produced by Oskar Barnack for Leica
Clarence H. White School of Photography in New York City is founded (will operate until 1942)
Bauhaus School founded in Dessau, Germany, with photography as a central component of its modernist arts cirriculum
Asahi Graph is first published in Japan
Time magazine first published
The Leica I camera is introduced to markets via the Leipzig Spring Fair in Germany, making 35mm film a consistent format for still photography
Invention of the modern flash bulb, by the General Electric company in the United States
Margaret Bourke-White begins working for Fortune magazine as its first staff photographer

New York's Museum of Modern Art holds its first one-man photography exhibition, "Walker Evans: Photographs of 19th century Houses." 1933 also marks the first year that the museum formally began collecting photographs.
Fuji Photo is established in Tokyo, Japan
Eastman Kodak markets Kodachrome film, the first mass-market subtractive method color film
The Kwanon', Japan's first 35 mm focal-plane-shutter camera, a copy of the Leica design, is prototyped by Canon
Olympus introduces its first camera, the Semi-Olympus I, which is fitted with the first Zuiko-branded lens
Life magazine is first published, and Margaret Bourke-White joins as its first female staff photographer
New York's Museum of Modern Art houses the exhibition "Photography 1839-1937," curated by Beaumont Newhall. It is the museum's first survey exhibition of photography.
Margaret Bourke-White and novelist Erksine Caldwell publish the photobook You Have Seen Their Faces , a study of race and poverty during the Great Depression in America's Deep South
Museum of Modern Art exhibits "Walker Evans: American Photographs," and publishes a book under the same title.
Museum of Modern Art holds the first exhibition organized by its newly created Department of Photography, "Sixty Photographs: A Survey of Camera Esthetics"
Eastman Kodak markets Kodacolor negative film
Walker Evans and the American writer James Agee publish Let Us Now Praise Famous Men , documenting the lives of sharecropper families during the Great Depression
Xerography is patented by Chester Carlson

The Museum of Modern Art establishes the Photography Center, with Willard D. Morgan as Director. Serving as a combined research and information center for photographers and photography enthusiasts, the Center also houses the archive and exhibition space for all photographs in the museum's collection.
Margaret Bourke-White flies as the first woman photographer to accompany an American bombing mission in World War II
Ansel Adams founds the first American fine-art degree program in photography, offered at the San Francisco Art Institute

Robert Capa, Henri Cartier-Bresson, William Vandivert, Rita Vandivert, Maria Eisner, George Rodger, and David “Chim” Seymour found the Magnum Photo Agency. As a cooperative, owned and operated by its members, the agency was created to equip professional photographers and photojournalists with a higher degree of creative freedom and copyright protection

Margaret Bourke-White publishes Dear Fatherland, Rest Quietly: A Report on the Collapse of Hitler’s “Thousand Years,” compiled after years of serving as a photojournalist on assignment in Germany and other European countries for Life magazine during World War II
Nikon introduces its first mass-market camera, the Nikon I
The first Polaroid instant camera, the Model 95, goes on sale in Boston, Massachusetts
The medium format Hasselblad camera is introduced
The George Eastman Museum opens in Rochester, New York
The Museum of Modern Art holds an exhibition entitled "Six Women Photographers: Margaret Bourke-White, Helen Levitt, Dorothea Lange, Tana Hobam, and Hazel and Frieda Larsen."
Drawing from the foundations of László Moholy-Nagy's New Bauhaus workshop program (1937), Chicago's Institute of Design begins to offer a Master of Science degree in photography
Henri Cartier-Bresson publishes Images à la Sauvette (The Decisive Moment) , a photobook that would become hugely influential for later twentieth-century photographers
Introduction of high-speed Tri-X film by Eastman Kodak

The Museum of Modern Art exhibition "Family of Man" is organized by Edward Steichen (then the director of the Department of Photography). The show brings together more then 500 photographs from nearly 300 photographers from around the world, and would go on to tour internationally for eight years.
The first Asahi Pentax SLR camera is introduced
Following from the success of the Pentax, Canon and Nikon introduce their own first versions of the SLR camera, the Canonflex and the F-Series
Kodak launches the Instamatic camera, a low-cost and easy-to-load point and shoot camera
Polaroid patents and markets one-step instant photography with the SX-70 camera
The International Center of Photography is founded in New York City by Cornell Capa

"New Japanese Photography" is exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Curated by John Szarkowski and Yamagishi Shoji, the exhibition is one of the first major museum shows in the United States devoted to avant-garde Japanese photography of the period
Kodak engineer Steve Sasson prototypes the first digital camera
Canon introduces the AE-1, the first camera to house a microcomputer
First point-and-shoot autofocusing camera (the C35 AF by Konica)
Ken Domon Museum of Photography opens in Sakata, Yamagata, Japan
Museum of Photographic Arts opens in San Diego, California (officially founded in 1974)
Fuji's Fujix DS-1P, a digital camera prototype, is unveiled at the Photokina trade show in Köln, Germany
Adobe Photoshop 1.0 is released for all Macintosh computer users
Tokyo Photographic Art Museum (originally the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Photography) opens in Tokyo, Japan
Magnum photo agency expands to Tokyo, Japan
Adobe Photoshop 1.0 is released for all Macintosh computer users
Kodak's first digital camera, the Kodak Digital Camera System (DCS) is introduced. It costs $20,000 USD and requires an external data storage unit
Kyocera Corporation launches the VP-210 VisualPhone, the first mobile phone with photographic and video functionality
Fuji's FinePix S1 Pro, the first interchangeable-lens DSLR targeted to amateur photographers, enters the global mass market
Legend
T = Technology
P = Professional (agencies, professional associations)
I = Institutional (schools and museums)
E/P = Exhibitions and Publications
